29.61.text:
Welcome to Fieldsports Britain. Coming up
we are in Sussex for the Sunday Times, shooting

36.00.text:
pheasants and deer. We are finding out how
they call in foxes in Scandinavia in a funny

41.20.text:
foreign language. We discover how you can
drink water from your local river without

46.12.text:
dying. First, we are going to Paris to shoot
partridge.

55.77.text:
Welcome to Browning's Research and Development
department. It may look very much like the

61.21.text:
beginning of a nice day's shooting - but don't
be fooled - this is serious stuff. Under the

67.30.text:
microscope is the new Browning 725, the new
Browning clothing range and a £45,000 B25

76.50.text: from Browning's custom shop in Belgium.

79.44.text:
To make sure the guns and the clothing get
a good work out we're at a game day on the

83.36.text:
outskirts of Paris. It's mostly partridge
but there will be the chance of pheasants,

88.89.text:
duck and grives too - that's the songthrush
to you and me, which is legal to shoot here

95.62.text:
At the first drive the Belgian guns line up
for the French shoot with the chance of some

100.79.text: very British weather - an interesting combination.

104.07.text:
So what makes a traditional French shoot apart
from a smart hat?

109.40.text:
This is a unique habitat. We have 750 hectares
of landscape with corn and mustard fields.

120.40.text:
This is where we shoot redleg and grey partridges
from September to end of November. We organize

136.11.text: three or four driven days a week.

139.87.text:
The birds are driven through the crops from
a mile or so away. By the time the partridges

148.99.text:
reach us they are travelling at a fair old
pace and a decent height.

153.56.text:
We're next to William - his R&D responsiblility
is clothing - and it's not just about how

160.02.text:
All the products are designed by shooters.
So we have a team internally who are all hunters

164.07.text:
and shooters, so we design the products in
house using our experience on the field and

172.27.text:
we test them extensively yes, so it is not
designer but of course the designer have their

178.40.text:
word on things to make them look nice. But
all the technical ....are designed by shooters.

185.69.text:
One piece of design he really likes is the
integrated recoil pads for those big bag days.

191.26.text:
We use these gel pads to reduce the recoil.
They are just there. They are very thin and

198.18.text:
slim so it doesn't affect the way you aim
at the birds and on the days when there are

203.66.text:
a lot of shoots they are perfect and it also
looks nice with the quilt and the very large

209.60.text:
pockets. It is a perfect jacket and you also
have a vest very nice as well. We will try

212.96.text:
them out today and hopefully have a very good
day with it.

219.32.text:
At the end of the drive the birds are laid
out for the guns to admire and appreciate

223.13.text:
- we're expecting a bag in excess of 200 today
so it's a good start with some fast shooting.

230.05.text:
We move further up the field for the second
drive - and we hear the distant calls of the

234.47.text: beaters in what seems to be the next province.

237.96.text:
We now share a peg with with Martin Boucquey.
He is doing invaluable work assessing the

243.06.text:
balance of the new B725 Hunter Grade 5. This
gun is an addition to the two 725 models already

250.40.text:
on offer. It will not be available until the
new year, so start saving that Christmas cash

258.60.text:
We had a sporting one, a hunter one and we
had to enlarge our range with a high level

267.64.text:
G5 one. Then we will also present the light
version of the B725 to have a bigger range.

280.49.text:
On the engraving you have a super engraving,
a duck, duck models on one side and you have

290.26.text:
pheasants on the other side. And then the
stock. You have a G5 stock model. So a really

296.67.text:
fine stock. Fine wood that you have on this
model.

300.52.text:
There is also a light version of the B725
coming soon too. In the meantime, Martin needs

302.76.text:
to put the Hunter G5 through its paces - plus
his Winchester cartridges. He is shooting

308.61.text: well - voila! a left and a right.

311.73.text: Or un double - which sounds cool.

316.08.text:
It's another good drive and there is lots
of shooting. This is a like a British driven

320.64.text:
shoot but the French character of the day
is unmistakable.

325.32.text:
We now head back to the house and drop down
to the next drive.First the guns walk through

330.19.text:
the maize before preparing for drive three.This
time we join Lionel. He is in charge of the

336.08.text:
custom shop in the factory in Leige and it
is a fascinating place resonating to the sound

341.81.text:
of the engravers, and with shelves and shelves
of hand selected wood ready to be brought

347.51.text:
to life. If you are watching this on YouTube,
click on the link to see our film about it.

353.48.text:
The B25 Lionel is shooting with today would
cost up to £45,000 and it's one of a pair...

360.02.text: but why spend so much money on a gun?

363.77.text:
You can go and do London to Brighton in a
Vauxhall and you can ride from London to Brighton

372.99.text:
in a Porsche or an Aston Martin. It is just
something different. It is a luxurious hand

382.18.text:
It takes about two years and hundreds of man
hours to produce a piece of art that shoots

387.59.text:
straight - and its Lionels job to make sure
each customer gets exactly what he or she

393.77.text:
My goal is to make the perfect gun for the
customer. And I think we make a few people

415.18.text:
The French-speaking labradors do their job
and once again the bag is presented to the

420.83.text:
We now adjourn to the house for food and a
little wine - which is much appreciated by

425.01.text:
the folk here. Talk around the table is about
the escalating price of birds - no change

431.77.text:
After lunch the drives continue to deliver
some fantastic sport - Again Martin finds

437.10.text:
the partridges and not many get past his right
side.

444.84.text:
The weather was not there, but the partridges
were there, really, and I got, not a double,

454.86.text: but that is for the next one.

458.16.text:
Some grey partridges are shot on this drive
and a few songthrushes - first you roast them,

465.77.text:
With one drive to go Jean-Christophe and his
team have delivered some great sport...so

470.61.text:
does that explain why he's wearing what looks
like a hat he's stolen off Postman Pat or

477.09.text:
This is a cap of a French private gamekeeper.
This symbol is a hunting horn - the legal

495.11.text:
William may be about 6 ft 3 but even he can't
see the partridges coming across the top of

499.58.text:
the maize crop on the last drive. Quick reactions
are needed here unless the birds come down

504.62.text: the line. William makes it look easy...

507.86.text:
This French shoot has been the same, but different.
All over Europe, driven game styles have their

513.28.text:
own identities. The Browning guys have shot
well here today and are pleased with how their

518.53.text: guns and gear perform in all conditions.

522.93.text:
All that's left is another tradition - the
laying out of the birds. The bag is 220 and

529.17.text:
it must take a certain mathematical brain
to be able to create such symmetry. It looks

537.09.text:
Well, I mentioned it during that piece, but
if you would like to watch our film about

541.84.text:
how they make those beautiful guns at Browning
in Liage then click on the screen if you are

547.17.text:
watching this on Youtube and you will go straight
through to the film.

550.18.text:
Now from la belle France to the belle of the
ball, it's David on the Fieldsports Channel

566.25.text:
Bird and animal attacks have been making the
news.

569.80.text:
A teenager whose hawk attacked a toddler has
been arrested by police. A two-year old in

573.92.text:
Hampshire had to have part of an ear reattached
by doctors after the Harris hawk attacked

578.72.text:
him. Last week, a Harris hawk in Scotland
attacked a terrier, tearing part of its tongue.

583.60.text:
The bird was later destroyed. Falconers are
fearful that these two incidents will lead

588.42.text: to calls for a ban on birds.

590.62.text:
Two incidents we have had recently are down
to inexperienced people flying hawks when

595.75.text:
they really shouldn't have been. Harris hawks
have been used for the last 20 years in demonstrations

600.86.text:
across the country at game fairs e.t.c. and
have been flown in front of millions of people

606.93.text:
Meanwhile a course angler from east Sussex
was attacked in his tent by a fox. 41 year

613.47.text:
old Andrew Thomas will have scars for life
after the incident which only ended when he

617.62.text: squeezed the fox's snout to stop it breathing.

621.95.text:
America has a new war. The US Department of
Defence and the American Wildlife Conservation

626.87.text:
Society has joined forces to combat the illegal
wildlife trade in Iraq and Afghanistan.

632.42.text:
One of the problems is American soldiers buying
hats made from snow leopards, so the society

638.27.text:
has produced this video aimed at informing
US military personnel about the consequences

643.36.text:
of buying illegal wildlife products when deployed
or stationed overseas.

649.94.text:
If you are voting in the police commissioner
elections in England and Wales on 15th November,

655.48.text:
watch out for some of the candidates. Animal
rights loony organisation IFAW has got more

660.98.text:
than 50 of them to agree to enforce the foxhunting
and coursing ban. Among the Labour, LibDem

666.28.text:
and Independent candidates are six antis from
the Conservative party standing in Greater

670.74.text:
Manchester, Cleveland, South Wales and Surrey.
To find IFAW's webpage google IFAW and 79491,

681.79.text:
George Digweed is the new brand ambassador
for the CENS ProFlex digital range of custom

687.09.text:
electronic shooters' plugs. With 20 World
titles, 16 European Titles and 10 World Cups

693.54.text:
to his name, George is a long-term user of
earmuffs. He will initially use the CENS ProFlex

699.08.text:
digital on his shoots, wirelessly interfacing
with the shoot radios. Puretone has been designing

704.51.text:
& manufacturing in the UK since 1976. For
more on the CENS range, visit www.censdigital.com

713.00.text: The Moorland Association has a new chairman.

715.70.text:
It is Robert Benson, who takes over the membership
organisation representing the owners and managers

720.23.text:
of over one million acres of moorland in England
and Wales. Formerly at Lowther Estates, Robert

726.28.text:
is a self-employed Cumbrian based sporting
and conservation manager

731.68.text:
The Countryside Alliance has launched a Young
Countryside Writer competition.

736.74.text:
It wants to give 12-18 year olds with a passion
for the countryside a chance to write for

740.47.text:
its membership magazine. All entrants need
to do is submit 300 words on what the British

745.29.text:
countryside means to them and what their favourite
aspects are, from farming, fieldsports, local

750.71.text:
food, the changing seasons, conservation to
just walking the dog.. Email your story to

763.47.text:
And finally, an American police officer shows
his cool when a moose gets stuck in a swing.

768.29.text:
The sheriff's sergeant from Utah helps cut
the animal loose. But will the animal gore

774.85.text:
him? In the end, he gets away with it. Even
the sergeant says it is lucky that everything

779.50.text: works out and the moose survives.

785.37.text:
You are now up to date with Fieldsports Britain
news. Stalking the stories. Fishing for facts.

796.99.text:
Thank you David. Beaten me to the hair cut
there. Now we are off to Sussex to a gormet

803.31.text:
pub to look at a whole lot of journalists
with their noses in the trough. I am not selling

807.99.text:
this am I? This is how you get the media to
love shooting.

815.33.text:
At the Horse Guards Inn in Petworth there
is a seven-course game menu being appreciated

824.81.text:
by food writers from the likes of the Sunday
Times and Lovefood.com.

828.94.text:
Once they've polished of the bullshot, game
scotch quail eggs, Vietnamese-style game broth,

834.87.text:
rabbit livers, wood sorrel and rabbit dumplings
it's going to be an early night, not just

839.87.text:
for the benefit of good digestion but because
at first light they'll be up a high seat or

844.41.text:
walking gingerly through the woods experiencing
deerstalking for the first time.

850.17.text:
Every journalist is allocated an experienced
stalker. We're joining Lucus who writes for

855.02.text:
The Sunday Times. He is being looked after
by Jack Smallman who runs South Downs Venison

861.48.text:
It is really very exciting. It is also really
nice just being out here at this time of the

877.45.text:
Unfortunately the weather is rubbish. Visibility
is down to just 20 yards - and although we

882.60.text:
can hear a rutting buck, there's no chance
of seeing him. Jack has honed his own selection

888.06.text:
of calls which seem to work impersonating
a new buck on the block and a youngster.

894.30.text:
With no chance or promise of a shot we resort
to plan B.

898.31.text:
While you are still out here, if we can we
will sneak down the side of the wood and try

901.43.text:
and come back with the wind still in our favour
and try and get a visual on it. Hopefully

909.54.text:
we will see some does and may be a pricket
with them and we might get a shot. We shall

912.82.text:
The fog gives us as much of an advantage as
the deer and we actually get quite close to

916.85.text:
the group - silhouttes pass in front of us
and a new buck has joined the party by the

921.50.text: sounds of it - antlers clash in the distance.

925.76.text:
Incredibly a young buck - an ideal cull animal
materialises out of the fog. Jack gets set

931.97.text:
up. He watches as opportunities come and go
as the fog ebbs and flows. As the buck passes

938.41.text:
by us broadside we prepare for the shot - but
it never comes and with good reason.

943.60.text:
Did you see that. When he went down there
he was safe ...but like ish. He wasn't brilliant.

950.30.text:
Then he came up to here where I would of quite
happily shot it. I could see it with my naked

955.71.text:
eye, but through the scope could not see it.
It just vanished. Every time I looked through

961.16.text:
it, I could just see a silhouette and I looked
through the scope I couldn't see a thing.

964.33.text:
And when it came back here I could see it
clear as day, but there was too much skyline

970.43.text:
behind and villagers and everyone else. I
was hoping it was going to come round, and

973.84.text:
if he came across and back in to try and come
back across the track, I would have had it,

977.48.text: but it decided to carry on up the field.

985.40.text:
Next on the Game To Eat menu is a local pheasant
shoot where we can grab a word with chef Lee

990.30.text:
Maycock and ask him why it's important for
the Countryside Alliance to drag journalists

996.95.text:
I think they have all seen enough, read enough
and heard enough so I think they just want

1000.83.text:
to do it at first hand. Actually getting them
into high seats in the mornings to get the

1006.49.text:
whole experience of being up in a high seat
at 6 o'clock in the morning watching the sun

1010.33.text:
come up, seeing the deer on the horizon. It
is fantastic. It is not the sort of thing

1013.57.text:
you do every day. So they can write from the
heart when they actually put these stories

1017.78.text:
together they can actually do it as first
hand experience and they can speak with depth

1022.80.text:
All the guests seem to be enjoying the experience.
Most of them have some understanding of the

1027.21.text:
importance of game and where it comes from.
However the name of the game today is to make

1031.78.text:
the meat accessible to a wider audience, and
they have the power to do that.

1036.60.text:
For me it was a real eye opener. It was nice
to see animals being taken and know that they

1042.39.text:
will be used. For me that is the most important
thing to think that although this is a bit

1047.23.text:
sport also to think of it as food. The more
we can do both in food media and both in retailers

1053.28.text:
and producers and other organisations, the
more we can do to promote game and make it

1059.96.text:
accessible, so sometimes people are going
to be put off by trying to roast a whole pheasant

1063.39.text:
bird when they are used to a chicken. I think
we need to look at what has happened to things

1066.97.text:
like duck where it has been broken down into
component parts so you have got quick things

1070.11.text:
to stir fry. People need to think a bit like
that, they plan meals not necessarily ingredients.

1075.80.text:
So we need to give the consumer a broader
range of choice and help and advise on recipes

1081.85.text:
sort of stuff. And the pheasant comes from
Georgia and I have been banging on all day

1085.11.text:
that we can get some interesting spices in
there, we can think about star anise and cinnamon

1090.76.text:
and saffron. These are
the things that come from the region where

1094.51.text:
the birds are originally from so people should
think it is not just game chips.

1099.38.text:
The drive is reasonably good with the dogs
working well. Even the apply named peanut

1106.03.text:
The next stop is Jack's chiller where the
guys have a chance to see the deer prepared.

1110.64.text:
They are now on familiar territory and enjoy
asking the butchers about cuts and preparation.

1115.52.text:
It appears the writers have had an eventful
day and Lucus has embraced everything that

1119.99.text:
was on offer, even just being in the great
British countryside...

1124.20.text:
As of a nation that is still, however urban
we have become, still has huge sways of countryside

1131.06.text:
which are managed by people who live in the
country, whether they are farmers or people

1134.68.text:
who run shoots. That is a very important part
of our national character I suppose. And it

1143.48.text:
is something that we should be preserving
and supporting and looking after. So it has

1149.29.text:
been, as much as anything, it has been a lovely
day out in the country actually with an early

1157.01.text:
This is the second time Jack has had the opportunity
to take people from the foodie press out on

1162.07.text:
field to fork adventure and he believes we
are making real progress with promoting game.

1167.10.text:
I think the public are now coming round to
the idea that we have got in the UK an absolutely

1173.47.text:
amazing product sat out there. It has got
to be managed. It is not just for the quality

1177.98.text:
of the deer and keeping the herd numbers under
control it is as much for looking after human

1182.83.text:
and farming interests as well. Certainly down
here on the South Downs we are trying to produce

1187.50.text: that and touch wood we are doing ok.

1190.73.text:
If you want to know more about the work of
the Game To Eat campaign, visit www.countryside-alliance.org.uk

1199.80.text:
Well if you like Lee you can see another of
our films. We went grouse shooting with him

1205.04.text: in the summer, just click on the screen.

1208.01.text:
Next we are off to our bushcraft expert Jonny
Crockett for a top tip on how to drink water

1224.90.text:
You can die of thirst faster than you can
die of hunger in the wilds. Water may be more

1230.29.text:
abundant than food, but it needs to be clean.
After years of trying all kinds of different

1236.02.text:
filters and techniques I have settled on the
simplest and the lightest.

1240.06.text:
What I need to get is some water to make the
soup, to make the tea, to make the stew. For

1248.12.text:
that what I am going to do is take this river
water. In the river we have all sorts of things,

1252.48.text:
we have got turbidity which as you can see
is the browny stuff in the water, the bits

1258.73.text:
of leaf, the dead insects the shopping trolleys,
then I have got parasitic worms and protozoas

1264.45.text:
and parasitic cysts and viruses and bacteria
and I have potentially got chemicals in there.

1269.51.text:
I am hoping because we are in Devon there
is not too much radiation, but you never know.

1274.69.text:
So what I am going to use to filter out the
turbidity and any of the larger particles

1280.10.text:
is a mill bank bag which is something that
the military have used for years. What you

1285.09.text:
do is you soak this in the water until it
is properly wet all the way through, keep

1294.64.text:
queezing it out so that it is soaked absolutely
soaked. Then what you do is you fill it up

1301.65.text:
with water right the way up to the top. Then
you leave it until the water gets down to

1309.08.text: that black line and that just rinses it

1310.73.text:
though. There we go. So I am going to wait
for that one to get down to the black line.

1323.51.text:
Then that one I can just put in like that
and that is taking all the turbidity out.

1332.44.text:
That doesn't make it good to drink all it
makes it is filtered not purified. To purify

1340.77.text:
it I can go down one of two routes. I can
either use chemicals like potassium permanganate,

1345.85.text:
iodine, chlorine or I can boil it. And boiling
it is what I am going to do. Gentle rolling,

1351.83.text:
simmering boil for about 4 minutes. And that
should be enough - that is certainly enough

1359.84.text:
for my cup of tea anyway. So I am now going
to tip this lot away and do another one.

1367.27.text:
We are bringing out a whole DVD with Jonny
later in the month. Watch the programme for

1375.41.text:
Now our old friend Ulf from Scandinavia has
brought out his own DVD about how to call

1381.53.text: in foxes. Let's take a peek.

1385.37.text:
We met the star of this new DVD, Ulf Lindroth,
when we went on the Zeiss fieldshooting trip

1391.76.text:
to Denmark. He is a phenomenal shot and it
is no surprise he won the fieldshooting competition.

1398.29.text:
A passionate shooter and all-round good guy,
he has brought out Fox Calling: The Right

1403.74.text:
Sound at the Right Place. Filmed on location
in Sweden, Norway and Denmark, it is in Swedish

1409.91.text:
but has English subtitles. Ulf describes all
his kit and how he uses it for the best results,

1416.51.text:
including how to stop a fox in the right place
to get a good shot. It is 93 minutes long

1422.84.text:
and expensive at £30 - but then damage from
foxes can be expensive too. Visit www.pantheon.se

1434.42.text:
From DVDs to the wider world of Youtube it
is Hunting Youtube.

1440.19.text:
This is Hunting YouTube, which aims to show
the best hunting, shooting and fishing videos

1446.44.text:
To the USA for top hunting video of the week,
which is The Best Female Taxidermist in the

1452.50.text:
South, with more 25,000 views. At once scary,
hilarious, gross and sweet, it tells the story

1459.03.text:
of Amy Ritchie, who is a hunter, a piano prodigy,
and a champion taxidermist. The interview

1464.89.text: takes place while she skins a fox.

1467.85.text:
Staying in the USA, 2012 Feral Hog Hunting
Highlights with the Dehogaflier shows highlights

1473.66.text:
from the 2012 pig hunting season in hunters'
heaven Louisiana. This year they had a thermal

1479.40.text:
scope as well as thermal camera. The majority
of the pigs taken are with a .308 equipped

1484.63.text:
with an ATN ThOR 640 two-and-a-half-magnification
scope.

1488.30.text:
Missouri rabbit hunt shows what fun you can
have with a friend, a girlfriend, a video

1493.29.text:
camera and a pack of hounds. TrackEmDownKennels
is out rabbiting in the undergrowth, shooting

1500.37.text:
Some say we don't see enough paint drying
on YouTube. I say we don't see enough match

1505.37.text:
fishing - and here is why I am right and everyone
else is wrong. Thom Airs presents British

1510.96.text:
Pike Championships Final 2012 in association
with GoFishing and Angling Times. Just two

1516.51.text:
ounces separated the top two anglers's catches
in a hard-fought British championship on the

1523.48.text:
Staying in the Fens, Catfishing with Mark
Barrett chasing dreams- episode 3 (video 77)

1529.51.text:
is presented by George Day who doesn't look
like he sees enough sun. In this film, he

1534.52.text:
reveals why. It's his dream to catch a daytime
UK catfish.

1538.91.text:
Back to shooting and there's a little competition
going between YouTube channels in the USA

1543.11.text:
as to who can set off the biggest legal explosion.
This latest is from GY6vids. Yeah - the one

1549.47.text:
in Swordfish is much better. But watch this,
pick up the promo code and you do get to claim

1554.63.text:
20% off explosives at the sponsoring website.
Kids, don't try this at home...

1559.57.text:
You hardly get more charming, sensible and
wonderfully British that Norfolk pheasants

1564.00.text:
by JamesMarchington. Gary Green hosts a day's
driven pheasant and partridge shooting at

1569.32.text:
the beginning of the season at Kilverstone
Hall Estate, Thetford in Norfolk, to Bach's

1573.78.text:
Brandenburg Concerto number four in G major,
which is of course the correct key for pheasant

1578.19.text: shooting in the Eastern Counties of England.

1580.67.text:
Finally, beautifully filmed with lots of dogs-eye-view
sequences, this Polish film could use subtitles.

1586.70.text:
If you can forgive that - and any Poles watching
can forgive my pronunciation of "mysliwy na

1591.57.text:
czterech lapach" - then watch this story about

1607.81.text:
Well if you like shooting, you will love the
Shooting Show.

1613.75.text:
On presenter Pete Carr's home turf just half
a mile from the East Yorkshire coast, it's

1619.18.text:
the first day of the duck shooting season
and he's been feeding the duck pond hard in

1623.52.text:
anticipation. The area is host to every duck
species shootable in the UK. As with any duck

1631.45.text:
flight, the action is fast, furious and demands
all of the pair's shotgun shooting skills.

1636.58.text:
Meanwhile, Byron Pace interviews wildlife
sculptor Ian Greensitt, a specialist in sculpting

1642.40.text:
game birds and game fish. If you are watching
this on YouTube, click on the link to watch
